etymologies: late Middle English: from Latin collocatio(n-), from collocare ‘place together’ (see collocate)

definitions: the habitual juxtaposition of a particular word with another word or words with a frequency greater than chance

examples.text: the words have a similar range of collocation

shortDefinitions: habitual juxtaposition of particular word with another word or words with frequency greater

definitions: a pair or group of words that are habitually juxtaposed

examples.text: “strong coffee” and “heavy drinker” are typical English collocations

shortDefinitions: pair or group of words that are juxtaposed in such way

definitions: the action of placing things side by side or in position

examples.text: the collocation of the two pieces

shortDefinitions: action of placing things side by side or in position
